statement.tex: %text Write the vector equation of a line given by $\dfrac{x=5}{3}=\dfrac{y+4}{7}=\dfrac{z-6}{2}$. %

step.context: %text Do the points $(5,-4,6)$ and $(8,3,8)$ lie on line $\dfrac{x-5}{3}=\dfrac{y+4}{7}=\dfrac{z-6}{2}$? %
step.tex: %text $(5,-4,6)$ and $(8,3,8)$ both lie on the given line. %
%text $(5,-4,6)$ does not lie on the given line but $(8,3,8)$ does. %
step.reason: \begin{align} &\dfrac{x-5}{3}=\dfrac{y+4}{7}=\dfrac{z-6}{2}=\lambda \text{ (say)} \\ \implies &x=5+3\lambda \\ &y=-4+7\lambda \\ &z=6+2\lambda, \, \text{where }\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$. \end{align} \\ %text Substituting $\lambda=0$ and $\lambda=1$ respectively in the above set of equations would result in points $(5,-4,6)$ and $(8,3,8)$. %

step.context: %text If $x=-5+3\lambda$, $y=4+7\lambda$ and $z=6+2\lambda$ specifies a vector $\ora{r}$, and $\ora{a}=\vector{-5}{4}{6}$ and $\ora{b}=\vector{3}{7}{2}$, what is the relation between $\ora{r}$, $\ora{a}$ and $\ora{b}$? %
step.reason: %text $\ora{r}=\vector{(-5+3\lambda)}{(4+7\lambda)}{(6+2\lambda)}$, can be expressed as the sum of the following two vectors - % \begin{align} \ora{r}&=\vector{(-5+3\lambda)}{(4+7\lambda)}{(6+2\lambda)} \\ &=-5\hat\imath+3\lambda\hat\imath+4\hat\jmath+7\lambda\hat\jmath +6\hat{\it \lambda}+2k\hat{\it \lambda} \\ &=\vector{-5}{4}{6}+\lambda(\vector{3}{7}{2}) \\ &=\ora{a}+\lambda(\ora{b}) \end{align}
